It is alÅ¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary to know the Å¿ituation of the Mannor of Epworth, which lyeth in length about Å¿ix miles, having Hatfield-ChaÅ¿e, and divers other waÅ¿ts (parcel of the Å¿aid 60000. acres, and belonging to other Mannors) on the WeÅ¿t, and the River of Trent adjoyning and running all along towards Humber on the EaÅ¿t; Å¿o as by conÅ¿equence (as well as by Proof in the depoÅ¿itions) it appears, that without cutting through the Mannor of Epworth, Hatfield-ChaÅ¿e, and the other waÅ¿ts lying on the WeÅ¿t could not have been drained; and therefore the Participants did but at their firÅ¿t coming into thoÅ¿e
parts, deÅ¿ire to cut through the Mannor of Epworth, without any further or other incroachment upon the Inhabitants there, for drawing the waters into the Å¿aid River of Trent, through the Å¿aid Mannor, to drain the Å¿aid ChaÅ¿e.

And although the Free-holders had Å¿uch a right in the Å¿aid grounds within the Mannor of Epworth, as hereafter will appear, could not by Law be improved againÅ¿t by any Lord of the Mannor; yet upon the draining of the Å¿aid ChaÅ¿e, and the other Mannors lying on the WeÅ¿t of Epworth, the Participants by colour of the late Kings illegal Patent, did about twenty years Å¿ince, by force of Arms, murdering Å¿ome, and wounding and impriÅ¿oning others of the Commoners, violently enter upon their Å¿aid grounds, and have for divers years much abuÅ¿ed, and grievouÅ¿ly oppreÅ¿Å¿ed them, forcing from them the Å¿aid Lands, (being the Free-holders ancient inheritance, and lying without the Å¿aid Level of Hatfield) granted to them about 300. years Å¿ince by a former Lord of the Mannor, in confirmation of the ancient right, which the Free-holders in thoÅ¿e times had, (for it is obÅ¿ervable, that the Deed makes mention, that at that time they had had right in thoÅ¿e grounds, time out of mind) and theÅ¿e Participants detained the Å¿ame Lands from them in the times of tyranny, by means of the Councel-Table and Star-Chamber, not Å¿uffering the Commoners to enjoy the benefit of the Law: yet Å¿ome of the Å¿aid Participants by their Agents Å¿o much abuÅ¿ed the Commoners, that even in thoÅ¿e times Å¿ome of them were cenÅ¿ured in the Star-Chamber to Å¿tand in the Pillory, and by dureÅ¿s of impriÅ¿onment, Å¿ore Fines, iÅ¿Å¿ues eÅ¿treated, threats and menaces againÅ¿t the Commons, and bribery (for they bribed the Sollicitor with 80. l.) Å¿ome few of the Inhabitants (the major part, and thoÅ¿e of the moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable, being free) were forced to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to Papers, the Contents whereof many of them never knew, as they anÅ¿wer upon their oaths in the Exchequer, but the Å¿ubÅ¿tance thereof indeed was, that they Å¿hould Å¿tand to the award of the Kings Attorney-General,
whoÅ¿e award (without hearing the merits of the cauÅ¿e) was ratified and confirmed by the Decree of Court of the Exchequer, in the twelfth year of the late King, as by the Decree it Å¿elf, if Mr. Gibbon durÅ¿t but Å¿hew the inÅ¿ide of it, would appear; for further then the outÅ¿ide of it, it hath not be Å¿hewn to any Committee: and yet there is Å¿ome mention made of it in the late Councels Order, wherein Mr. Gibbon was certainly beholden to the Clerk that drew it; as if that Decree Å¿hould hold place, notwithÅ¿tanding the Participants own laÅ¿t Decree of the 10. of Febr. 1650. and the Free-holders verdict at Law to the contrary. Now though Mr. Gibbon cannot abide to hear of the Title, and the proceedings that have of late been at Law in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s (thinking to dam all up with the noyÅ¿e he hath made of a Riot) and though the Title hath hitherto been refuÅ¿ed to be heard or medled with by any Committee of Parliament, yet the Free-holders rely upon that as their main Å¿trength, and do look upon your Honors as the only refuge they have under God to preÅ¿erve their rights according to Law, from the violation of thoÅ¿e, that againÅ¿t Law endeavour to uÅ¿urp a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion: and having Å¿everal rights to the ground in queÅ¿tion, as not onely common appendant, but alÅ¿o common in groÅ¿s, (though the former be certainly included in the latter) they humbly lay down their Å¿everal Titles as followeth) and firÅ¿t as to common appendant.

The Free-holders and Commoners within the Mannor of Epworth, have time out of mind, had common appendant to their Å¿everal Tenements, for all manner of Cattel, Levant and Couchant thereupon, at all times of the year, in and through all the waÅ¿ts and commons within the Å¿aid Mannor, (whereof the grounds in controverÅ¿ie are the greateÅ¿t part, and was alwayes of the beÅ¿t nature) and in confirmation of this their ancient right, Sir John Mowbray, Å¿omtime Lord of the Å¿aid IÅ¿le, having in his time made an approvement of part of the Å¿aid waÅ¿ts to himÅ¿elf, as Lord, did about 300. years Å¿ince grant unto the Free-holders by
an ancient Charter in French, but here tranÅ¿lated into EngliÅ¿h by William Riley, Keeper of the Records in the Tower, as followeth.

THis Indenture between their thrice Honored Lord Sir John Mowbray, Lord of the IÅ¿le of Axholm, and of the Honor of Brember, of the one part; Rawlin of Brumham, William of Brumham, Roger of Brumham, John of Thetilthorp, Thomas Melton, Jeoffrey Laundels, Vincent Bavant, John Gardner, John Cutwolfe, Richard of Belwood, and John at Hagh, his Tenants of the IÅ¿le of Axholm, and all the tenants and reÅ¿iants within the Å¿aid IÅ¿le, on the other part, WitneÅ¿Å¿eth, that all the Å¿aid tenants and reÅ¿iants have Å¿upplicated their Å¿aid Lord Sir John Mowbray, to have remedy of divers claims touching their right, and divers debates and grievances to them made by the MiniÅ¿ters of the Å¿aid Lord Sir John Mowbray: upon which Å¿upplication it is agreed, that the Å¿aid Sir John Lord aforeÅ¿aid, hath granted for him and for his Heirs, to the Å¿aid Rawlin, William, Roger, and John, Thomas, Jeoffrey, Vincent, John, John, Richard, and John, tenants aforeÅ¿aid, and to their Heirs, and to all, having their eÅ¿tate, or parcel of their estate, and to all the other tenants and reÅ¿iants within the IÅ¿le of Axholm, and to their Heirs, and to all that hereafter Å¿hall have their estate, all the things underwritten, that is to Å¿ay, that the Å¿aid Sir John, nor his Heirs, Å¿hall not approve any WaÅ¿te, Moors, Woods, Waters, nor make, or Å¿hall make any other approvement of any part within the Å¿aid IÅ¿le of Axholm; and that the Å¿aid Rawlin, William, Roger, John, Thomas, Jeoffrey, Vincent, John, John, Richard, and John, and their Heirs, and thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall have their eÅ¿tate, or parcel of their eÅ¿tate, and all other tenants and reÅ¿iants within the IÅ¿le of Axholm, Å¿hall have their common, which is appendant to their free tenement, according to that which they have had, and uÅ¿ed, time out of mind.
Note, that 33. Edw. 3. the Freeholders had then had Common time out of minde. And alÅ¿o that the aforeÅ¿aid Rawlin, William, Roger, John, Thomas, Jeoffrey, Vincent, John, John, Richard, and
John, and their Heirs, and all thoÅ¿e which their eÅ¿tate, or parcel of their eÅ¿tate Å¿hall have, and all other the tenants and reÅ¿iants within the aforeÅ¿aid IÅ¿le, may dig in the Moors and MarÅ¿hes, turfs, trees, and roots, found within the Å¿oil of the Å¿aid Moors and MarÅ¿hes; and that one pound, containing one half acre, be made at the coÅ¿t of the Å¿aid tenants, and maintained hereafter by the Å¿aid Lord and his heirs in Belton-car, and one other in Haxey-car, containing as much, and that they be made in places for the moÅ¿t eaÅ¿e of the Å¿aid tenants; and that no ChaÅ¿e of BeaÅ¿ts of Commoners be made, but once a year; and that the Å¿aid BeaÅ¿ts be not otherwiÅ¿e driven, but to the pound of the PaÅ¿ture where they Å¿hall be taken, and there the BeaÅ¿ts of the Å¿aid tenants to be delivered by the tenants aforeÅ¿aid, or by their Å¿ervants: and Å¿aving alwayes to the Å¿aid tenants, and to their heirs, and to their Å¿ervants, that they may take their BeaÅ¿ts, and receive them in the drift, or before the drift, Å¿o that the drift of BeaÅ¿ts of Å¿trangers, be not thereby diÅ¿turbed: And that in the Å¿everalities of the Å¿aid Lord adjoyning to the places in which they have Common, which are open, and not incloÅ¿ed, no BeaÅ¿ts of the Å¿aid tenants and Commoners be taken, nor impounded, but eaÅ¿ily driven out: And that the Å¿aid tenants and reÅ¿iants, and their heirs, and all thoÅ¿e which their eÅ¿tate, or parcel of their eÅ¿tate Å¿hall have, may dig, and take turf, or other earth, for the walls of their houÅ¿es, and for all other neceÅ¿Å¿aries of the Å¿aid houÅ¿es, and for to incloÅ¿e the walls of their MeÅ¿Å¿uages or ManÅ¿ions; and to dry Flags in all the Å¿aid wasts, for to cover the ridges of their houÅ¿es and walls, and for bringing of trees to repair the river of Trent, where cauÅ¿e of repairing is, and to make them new.
